Retirees from the Bayelsa state civil service under the aegis of Nigerian Union of Pensioners were attacked in front of the Government House while they were protesting unpaid gratuity by a group that they allege was hired by the state government. A conflicting witness claims there was not violence.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 3 protesters in Metta village, Jimma Arjo, East Welega.
A woman was killed and two other civilians were injured following after security forces open fire to disperse local people that tried to storm Baidoa hospital searching for their family members.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Magado village, Shakiso District, Guji zone. Three people were killed and more than 15 wounded by soldiers.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Waliso , Shewa. Soldiers allegedly fired at protesters.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Dallo Mana, Bale. Soldiers opened fire on them.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Security forces shot and killed a protester in Tenzet village, Begi District, West Welega
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Dabaso town, Nole Kaba district, West Welega. At least one protestor was shot by soldiers
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Furda, Bedeno district. At least two people were injured by soldiers.
A secondary school student is shot and killed by security forces when a protest erupted after police attempted to stop a football match.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Micheta town. At least one person was shot by soldiers.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Security forces shot and killed 5 protesters against the national agenda in Buri village, Gidami district.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Soldiers allegedly killed two protesters in Guto Mexi village, Bako Tibe District, West Shawa.
People protested in Aramuri and Ulaga in Bedeno. In Ulaga, soldiers shot and killed at least one protester.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Buri village, Gidami district, Qelem Wallaga. Soldiers shot at protesters killing at least five and wounding dozens.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Begi and Buri, Gidami. In Buri, soldiers shot and killed at least five protesters.
Security forces shot and killed a protester in Qalina, East Harerge.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in West Arsi.
Oromo students protested against the national agenda in several schools in Nekemt. Soldiers fired on them to prevent them from marching to the centre.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Beigi, West Welega. At least two persons were shot and killed.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Daandii
notes: Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Arramuri and Ballina villages in Bedeno district. Soldiers shot at protesters, killing at least five

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Daandii
notes: Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Mechara. Military forces opened fire on protesters, killing at least 7 (upper estimates are 9 dead) and severely injuring another 16.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: One student shot dead and five injured by soldiers breaking up an anti-rape protest.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Chalanqo town, Metta district, East Harerge. Soldiers fired at protesters, killing at least one.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Awaday. At least one person was shot by soldiers
Oromo students protested against the national agenda near Haramaya university. Soldiers shot at protesters.
Security forces shot and killed four protesters in Sasiga, East Harerge.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Dawe town, blocking the road to Badano to soldiers. At least one was injured.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Nekemt. Soldiers allegedly shot and severely injured at least two.
Oromo people protested against the national agenda in Bedeno, Bedeno district. At least one person was shot and killed by soldiers.
Soldiers shot at protesters in Nekemt. At least two are said to have been killed.

Unidentified individuals fire on miners protesting against expulsion from a mine. The mine is owned by the presidents son who is accused of ordering the gunmen to fire. One person is missing and has not been confirmed as dead or alive. The gunman is later identified as a non-commissioned military officer.
People protested against the national agenda in Nekemt. Gun fire spread to various part of the city. At least five people were shot by soldiers and severely injured.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: People protests against the national agenda in Gimbi town, West Wallaga. Soldiers shot and killed a protester.
Soldiers killed one person in Dodola and injured two others in protests against the government agenda.
Soldiers allegedly shot at at least two protesters in Ambo, killing one and leaving the other with severe injuries.
Soldiers shot at protesters in Nekemt, injuring dozens of people.
People protested against the national agenda in Abaro village near Shashamane. Government soldiers fired on protesters killing at least four

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Soldiers allegedly killed a protester along the Guder-Ambo corridor
Police arrested and detained a protester living near Addis Ababa following protests the previous day. He was allegedly taken to a military camp and tortured.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: People protested against the national agenda in Dire Gammachis, Mojo Asha and Chaffe Jannata villages, Girawa district. Soldiers killed three people.
People protested against the national agenda in Kokosa, West Arsi. Soldiers shot at protesters, killing at least one.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Youth protested against the national agenda in Shashamane and in nearby Shagule and Jigessa villages. Three people were killed by government soldiers.
People protested against the national agenda in Asasa (West Arsi). Soldiers shot at protesters, killing one.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: People protested against the national agenda in Dodola town (West Arsi). Soldiers fired at them killing one and wounding at least six.
People protested against the national agenda in Alibo town, Jarte district, Horo Guduru. Soldiers shot at protesters
Students protested against the national agenda in Nejo. Soldiers conducted house to house search arresting dozens of people. One student was shot by soldiers and in critical condition.
People protested against the national agenda in Dogo town of Girawa district. Soldiers shot at protesters.

source: Oromia Media Network; Human Rights Watch
notes: Over 15,000 people marched to Shashamane to protest against the government agenda. Soldiers shot at protesters. At least one person was killed.
Protests against building of Kajbar and Dal dams. Police used batons and tear gas to disperse protesters, and arrested 30 at the protests. 9 severely beaten and injured.
People protested against the national agenda in Kofele, blocking all roads to and from the city. Soldiers reinforcements were sent to the town. They killed five people and wounded several.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in East Hararge.
People protested against the national agenda in Wabe town, Kofele District. At least one person was shot and severely injured by soldiers.
Soldiers reportedly killed a student protester in Chaffe Jannata village, Girawa District, East Hararghe.
Soldiers reportedly killed a protester in Elemo, Girawa district, East Hararghe.
People protested against the national agenda in Senbete town,West Arsi. Soldiers allegedly killed four people.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: People protested against the national agenda in Aje town, West Arsi. Soldiers shot and killed five protesters.
People protested against the national agenda in Shashamane, blocking the main road passing through the city. Police killed three people in its effprts to quell the protest.

source: Jordan News Agency (Petra); Palestine News & Information Agency (WAFA)
notes: On Feb 14, during a raid on Arrub refugee camp in Hebron, an Israeli army jeep ran over and seriously injured a Palestinian boy. Locals sources said the boy was deliberately struck by the jeep during an anti-Israeli march by schoolchildren in the refugee camp, where troops killed a young Palestinian last week.

On Feb 14, Shiite Bahrainis took to the streets in many location and areas in Bahrain, around 46 demonstrations in 26 areas, including 12 marches suppressed by security forces. The information said that many marches scheduled to occur but the extensive presence of security forces restricted the start of these marches. Also, 21 cases of arrests were reported, and many injuries occurred during the repression of these peaceful marches, 4 of which were major.

2 protesters were hospitalized after being beaten by police during a march by at least 100 demonstrators organized by the ZAA, YARD and ROHR. They were marching to demand "the current ZANU-PF-led government show love to its people and stop looting the nations resources".
On 12 Feb. 2016, 7 civilians were attacked and injured by a group of masked people, while protesting in downtown Nassriyah, Thi-Qar. No reported fatalities
Farmers protested against the national agenda from Chifra Misra village in Dobba District. A young man was wounded by soldiers

On February 10, a group of people gathered in Baglar neighborhood of Diyarbakir to protest against the military operations. Police forces reportedly opened fire on protesters, killing one and injuring two.

Turkish forces reportedly started military operations on February 10 in central Esentepe, Esenyurt ve Gungor neighborhoods of Yuksekova/Hakkari. Civilians protested against the military forces and one civilian was reported to have been killed.

On February 9, police forces intervened in a march organized in central Diyarbakir by residents of Baglar and Yenisehir districts, against the military operations in Cizre. One child was shot to death during this intervention.
Police open fire on an otherwise peaseable IOPB protest in Aba on 09/02. Six dead, injuries reported, plus arrests.
Defense forces tried to demolish shops in Kadugli market. Owners protested. Police and army fired shots in the air, injured citizens taken to hospital.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Nekemt.
Protesting bus drivers and their supporters were attacked by a rival association armed with sticks, metal bars and hammers. Police arrested two protesters, but none of the attackers.
Members of a tuk-tuk drivers' association accused of working with a bus company beat a group of bus drivers who were protesting the company after a mass firing.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed an Oromo student protester at Dilla University.

On Feb 5th, Shiite Bahrainis took to the streets in Sitrah, including Ash Shakhurah and Abu Saybi area , as part of an ongoing agitation for reform begun on February 14th, 2011. The information reported violent repression by police forces, where they used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd of peaceful protesters. Several major injuries were reported.

On Feb 5th, Shiite Bahrainis took to the streets in Sitrah, including Ash Shakhurah and Abu Saybi area , as part of an ongoing agitation for reform begun on February 14th, 2011. The information reported violent repression by police forces, where they used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd of peaceful protesters. Several major injuries were reported.
People protested against the government agenda in Bule Hora as part of the third round of Oromo protests. Soldiers shot and killed at least two protesters.
People protested against the government agenda in Arjo as part of the third round of Oromo protests. Soldiers shot and killed at least one protester.
More than 3,000 Oromia people protested in Bulehora town. Soldiers fired at protesters, killing at least one and wounding three. Protesters burnt down the Revenue Office in retaliation.
A doctor is shot by police during a protest and strike by medical staff. It is not clear is the shot was fatal.

actor1: Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: NISS allegedly beat and arrested a group of 15 women in Khartoum for staging a protest demanding accountability for the 2013 anti-austerity protest killings. Although human rights organisations documented that more than 170 individuals were killed, Sudanese authorities have acknowledged just 85 deaths.

At least three Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) employees were killed as Rangers and police personnel launched a baton and tear gas attack on anti-privatisation strikers near Karachi's Jinnah Terminal, resulting in suspension of the national flag carrier's flight operations across the country.
Violence during a protest led to the death of two protesters and injuries to several others during a demonstration by PIA employees in Karachi.

Parents, led by the Nationalist Coloured Party, protested in Sidwell in the Neslon Mandela Metropolitan Area. A heavy police presence prevented them from entering the buillding in which one protester was allegedly injured by police when the protesters attempted to get through the wall of police officers.

Street protests turned violent after security forces tried to break up anti-government match in Bosasso town on 01/02. Puntland soldiers fired into the air with volleys of gunfire being heard across the city. The protesters were taking to streets in support of detained Youth leader identified as Abdiasis Farah Haji Saed. Two deaths reported.
Students protested to demand payment of scholarships and were dispersed by police, who reportedly used violence and teargas, causing injuries.
On January 31, in Gazi neighborhood of Sultangazi/Istanbul, police forces intervened a protest and reportedly shot a protester in the leg.

On January 30, two children were shot and injured as police forces opened fire during a protest in central Seyhan district of Adana (Barbaros neighborhood). On February 4, one of the children died in the hospital.
Israeli forces supressed the weekly protest in Nabi Salih. A foreign activist was injured with live bullet fired by the Israeli forces.

Students at Walaga university in Nekemt protested against the Governments master plan. They were met by violent repression from soldiers on the campus. Several students were injured and rest are chased out of campus into the adjacent forest.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Arjo Gudatu, East Welega.

Protesters, including workers and students, gathered at Tuts University in ongoing fees protests. Following, these protesters were attacked by SASCO members who emerged with bricks and bottles, which they began to throw at the workers who were sitting down. One worker was injured and was bleeding heavily.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Arjo Gudetu village, Digga District, East Welega
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Doba.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Shenen.
People protested in East Walaga, Digga district, Arjo Gudetu village. Ethiopian soldiers fired on protesters, wounding at least three. One of them later died of his wounds.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed an Oromo student protester at Mizan Tepi University in the Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples Region.
Students at Walaga university in Nekemt protested against the Governments master plan. They were met by violent repression from soldiers on the campus.
On January 24 in Adana, police forces intervened in protests against curfews in southeastern Turkey. One person was shot and injured.
On January 24, police intervened in the protests in Kucukcekmece, Istanbul against curfews in southeastern Turkey. One person was shot and heavily injured with risk of paralysis.
Authorities intervened violently to disperse a demonstration by Saharawi activists, causing several injuries.
Reports that soldiers continue to harass civilians. The soldiers shot and injured 3 young men in this latest violence.
11 students have been injured when soldiers attacked Walaga University students in Naqamte
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a student protester in Goban, Jimma Rare District, Horo Guduru.
Protests continue in Asabot (West Hararge). People marched through the town. Federal police and soldiers have fired on them, killing two and wounding several.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in East Hararge.

actor2: Police Forces of Ethiopia (1995-2018) Liyu Police
notes: Protests continued in Mieso. The regime deployed Somalia regions Liyu Police, killing 2 people.

Police open fire on a group of IPOB protesters on Aba, calling for the release of their jailed leader, Nnamdi Kanu. Eight reported dead, 30 injured, 26 arrested. The protest was characterised as peaceful by most sources, though The Nation newspaper reported the IBOP clashed with security agents.

source: Oromia Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Protests continued in the town of Mieso. TPLF soldiers reportedly killed five people and wounded at least three.
People protested against the government agenda in Awara, G. Beret as part of the third round of Oromo protests. Soldiers shot and killed at least one protester.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Ginde Beret, West Shewa.

Students protested against the national agenda in Bedeno in January 2016. Security forces fired at protesters, shooting at least six and killing at least one, while police arrested at least one student.

source: Oromiya Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Protests occurred in Shenen town, Jibat district (West Shawa). Students marched from school to the town. Federal police fired on them injuring several who being treated at clinic right now

At least two elderly women were injured, one of them seriously when police allegedly lobbed teargas shells to disperse them after the protesters blocked traffic on Boulevard road in Nishat in the outskirts of Srinagar city.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: People protested against the government agenda in Ambo as part of the second round of Oromo protests. One student protester was killed by soldiers.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: People protested against the government agenda in Masalaha as part of the second round of Oromo protests. The body of a protester was found in nearby Abadi village the same day.
A protest is underway in Agarfa ( Bale). The military has responded by firing on students. Several causalities feared.

Pictures show soldiers kicking student in the head at the Dadar High School ( East Hararge). Students reportedly staged peaceful silent walk through the campus. Soldiers then came, gathered them in the field and began beating them

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Wadesa.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed two protesters in Adaba.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Midekign, West Shewa.
In another event, 2 people were shot by soldiers near Haromaya University this morning.

source: Oromiya Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project
notes: Students at Ambo university protested against the government master plan. Security forces responded violently, allegedly killing one student.
Private security guards allegadly used violence to remove students who were occupying building at Wits University
Protests after funerals for those killed in riots the day before. Police fired tear gas and shots in the air. 3 killed, 5 taken to hospital suffering the effects of tear gas.

A protest is underway at the Haromaya University. Soldiers in the area are reportedly breaking into dormitories assaulting students.At least 3 students said to have been killed following overnight assault on Haromaya University student dormitories.
Protests at the Madda Walabu University resulted in two students being killed when soldiers fired on students.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in West Shewa.
Protests kicked off for a third round at the Madda Walabu University. Soldiers apparently have engaged students, detaining hundreds and firing live ammunition. One protester killed.

source: Philippines Daily Inquirer, SunStar Cagayan de Oro
notes: Armed men, allegedly led by Rommel Arnado who is the mayor of Kauswagan municipality, as well as members of the civil security unit shot at protesters outside the municipal hall in Kauswagan, Lanao del Norte on 9 Jan 2016, wounding at least three of them. Rommel Arnado is currently banned from running for elections and is in conflict with candidates for upcoming May 2016 elections, which could have served as a pretext for the event.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in the Southern Nations, Nationalities and Peoples Region.
In Bil'in village, Israeli soldiers fired dozens of gas bombs and rubber-coated steel bullets at the weekly nonviolent protest against the Wall and the settlements, causing dozens of injuries.
A protest was reportedly underway in Asabot. Farmers came marching were joined by towns residents. Reportedly, heavily armed TPLF soldiers attacked these peaceful protesters.

source: Morocco World News; Human Rights Watch
notes: Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. Around 100 were injured in Inezgane, where the level of violence was especially high.

source: Morocco World News; Human Rights Watch
notes: Teacher trainees held sit-ins and were met with "extreme violence" from the police. Around 20 were injured.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Hirna.
Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. A total of over 280 protesters were injured throughout the nation.

source: Morocco World News; Human Rights Watch
notes: Between 800 and 2,000 teacher trainees marched in Casablanca to protest several policies and police used "excessive force" to disperse them. Around 40 were injured.

source: Morocco World News; Human Rights Watch
notes: Teacher trainees were beaten by police while protesting. Around 8 were injured.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Gachi.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a Welega university student protester in Nekemt.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Horo Guduru.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Muger, Adda Berga.
One person killed and two wounded in people protests against the governments master plan in Masala on 5 January

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch

Security forces allegedly arrested and killed a student at Wollega university in Nekemt on 4 January in connection with the protests against the governments master plan

assoc_actor_1: RTUZ: Rural Teachers Union of Zimbabwe
notes: During a protest led by the Rural Teachers Union of Zimbabwe (RTUZ), police aggressively suppressed the march, arresting and beating some protesters.

The Army opened fire on protesting farmers, killing at least one and wounding around 30 others on 1 April 2016 in Kidapawan City, Cotabato. The farmers had staged a protest at the National Food Authority in Kidapawan City against government neglect at a time of drought, demanding rice subsidies and relief.
Farmers,businessmen, towns residents and youth marched in Hirna town, West Hararge, to protest against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Students protested against the governments master plan in Shashamane and were met by violent response from police forces
Soldiers throwed hand grenades at protesting students at Dilla university, killing five
Protests against the governments master plan at Lagahare Scondary school in Dire Dawa were met by violent response from police forces. Several students were arrested
Health professionals protested at Jimma University against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Youth in Nekemte protested against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Students and other people protested in Sibu Sire against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Students at Shambu Prep School staged sit-ins in the school compound to protested the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Soldiers throwed hand grenades at protesting students at Dilla university, killing five over two days

Bahrainis took part in an anti-regime protest in Abu Saybi neighbourhood in Manama. The Bahraini police intervened and opened prohibited weapons to disperse the protesters, during which a number of demonstrators were injured.

Bahrainis took part in an anti-regime protest in Ash Shakhurah neighbourhood in Manama. The Bahraini police intervened and opened prohibited weapons to disperse the protesters, during which a number of demonstrators were injured.
Protests against the governments master plan erupted in Gida Ayana High school and were met by violent response from police forces
Protest expand from Mechara to Micheta against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
Students protested at a school in Nekemte and were met by violent response from police forces
Soldiers throwed hand grenades at protesting students at Dilla university, killing five over two days
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Gabate, Horo Guduru.
Students and farmers protested in Mechara town against the governments master plan. Soldiers reportedly fired at protesters. At least one student was wounded
Students protested in Jimma against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces

notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Alibo.
Students and farmers protested in Mechara town against the governments master plan. Soldiers reportedly fired at protesters. At least one student was wounded
Soldiers reportedly beat students as they exited their dormitories at Ambo Universitys Awaro Campus
Soldiers shot at least six people protesting the governments master plan in Jardega Jarte district (Horo Guduru). One teacher died and the others are in critical condition.
Students protest at Walaga University against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces
2 students killed, 11 injured in protests against bread shortages. Police fired live ammunition, tear gas and used batons to disperse the crowd. Several arrested.

Students protest at Agarfa High School against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces

Students protested against the government master plan and for the release of imprisoned students in Shashamane end December. Police and soldiers fired teargas at the protesting students, and beat and arrested some of them. When new students tried to prevent the arrests, the security forces responded with more gunfire, killing one. They later went door to door to arrest protesters.
Students at Wolloga University (Nekemte) protested against the governments master plan and were met by violent response from police forces

One student was allegedly killed in clashes between student protesters and police forces in Abuna town, Gindabarat district. Students have been protesting in several parts of the country against the governments renewed plans to implement a master plan for the expansion of Addis Abeba.

source: Oromiya Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Six people were allegedly killed in clashes between student protesters and police forces in Adaba town, West Arsi. There are also reports of injuries and arrests. Students have been protesting in several parts of the country against the governments renewed plans to implement a master plan for the expansion of Addis Abeba.
Police arrested and hit students in Hidilola following protests against the master plan the previous day.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Gedo.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 2 protesters in Lalo Asabi.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 2 protesters in Asgori.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 3 protesters in Ginde Beret.
People protested against the government agenda in Bako as part of the second round of Oromo protests. Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed 5 protesters in Babich.

Police and students clashed in Arsi early December. Gunfire was shot and police went door to door to arrest the protesters. In one place where they arrested 7 students, they also beat and arrested a civilian for hiding them.

source: Oromiya Media Network; Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Daandii
notes: Seven people have been confirmed dead in Waliso in clashes between student protesters and police forces. No reports of protester violence.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed two protesters in Inango.

On 30 October 2015, a labour rally was held in Jakarta city. The police arrested 25 demonstrators and beat several of them including two legal aid activists monitoring the event. The legal aid activists reported being beaten and suffering injuries to the head, face and stomach what the demonstrations began to disperse. Detainees were released after being charged with threatening public officials and refusal to disperse. [size=25]
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 2 protesters in South West Shewa.
Student peaceful protests at Ambo university were met by violence from police forces who sought to prevent the protest from taking place.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 2 protesters in South West Shewa.

On 8th December, Prison administration proceeded to beat and torture hunger striking prisoners at Al-Aqrab prison after they started a hunger strike. 25 of the injured have not been allowed any medical care.
Police execute 2 protesters after they had been arrested and released in Bujumbura.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a student protester at Haramaya university.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch; Daandii
notes: Security forces allegedly shot and killed two protesters in Inchini.

Haramaya high school students protested following the governments renewed plans to implement a master plan for the expansion of Addis Abeba. One student who joined the protest rally was shot by the police and died
Security forces allegedly shot and killed 3 protesters in Fincha.

Moroccan forces "violently dispersed a peaceful demonstration" of Saharawis protesting unemployment rates. Several injured.
Security forces allegedly shot and killed a protester in Tole, South West Shewa.

source: Ethiopia Human Rights Project; Human Rights Watch

On Dec 1, in Serui, a person was shot dead by Indonesian police and two are critical during a protest against Indonesian rule over the eastern region of Papua.

Violent clashes erupted between protesting workers and anti-riot forces in Rouiba. The demonstrators were claiming the payment of their overdue salaries. Dozens of injuries among the protesters and over twenty arrests were reported.

On December 1, 2015, in Wanampompi village in Angkaisera district (Yapen Islands, Papua), Papuan pro-independence activists staged a rally and police used lethal force to intervene and disperse the activists, killing four people and injuring 8 others.

Three students at Haramaya University, near Harar, were wounded when police fired live bullets against protesting students. High school and university students protested in several cities located in the Oromiya regional state following the governments renewed plans to implement a master plan for the expansion of Addis Abeba. The protestors are however met by excessively armed police men.

Protest started at Adama university in the last week of November in response to the increasing numbers of federal and regional police forces on the compound. Police responded with gunfire and three days of chaos and persistent protests ensued. An unspecified number of students were reportedly injured. No reports of demonstrator violence.

Protest started at Adama university in the last week of November in response to the increasing numbers of federal and regional police forces on the compound. Police responded with gunfire and three days of chaos and persistent protests ensued. An unspecified number of students were reportedly injured. No reports of demonstrator violence.

Protest started at Adama university in the last week of November in response to the increasing numbers of federal and regional police forces on the compound. Police responded with gunfire and three days of chaos and persistent protests ensued. An unspecified number of students were reportedly injured . No reports of demonstrator violence.

Protest started at Adama university in the last week of November in response to the increasing numbers of federal and regional police forces on the compound. More than 600 students gathered at the canteen for lunch and received their lunches but left their plates untouched. Police responded with gunfire, injuring students and persistent protests ensued. No reports of demonstrator violence.
Youth protest against police arrests in Ngagara. Police injure several, including shooting one protester in the foot.

actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)
notes: The PNC brought up a strike actions by workers from the roads sector which involved blocking a convoy of vehicles. The police allegedly fired shots and assaulted the drivers, wounding some.
Two protesters were seized by gunmen after a small group of relatives and friends commemorated the second anniversary of the Gharghour killing.
Police in Harare have reportedly beaten up scores of demonstrating students. Several are said to have been badly injured and others arrested.
Police forces violently suppressed demonstrations against the Chinese president's visit to Vietnam, beating and detaining dozens of protestors.
Police forces violently suppressed demonstrations against the Chinese president's visit to Vietnam, beating and detaining dozens of protestors.

PDP supporters attack a group of protesting APC members, suspected at the direction of the governor. The group was protesting a neglected garbage dump site. In retaliation, APC members attack a PDP campaign group (date unknown; soon after). No injuries reported from either attack.
Authorities "brutually repressed" a protest against the kings visit to the Western Sahara, causing two injuries.

On Monday, students and workers occupied vice-chancellor Ihron Rensburgs office and demanded that he immediately end outsourcing. The group was assaulted by private security guards during their sit-in.
An elected councillor was killed by unidentified assailants while 4 others were injured at a rally in Faisalabad.

A group of tuk-tuk drivers (tri-cycle) staged a peaceful demonstration at Sayidka Junction (Hawl-Wadaag District) in the morning of 26/10 in protest against banning of tuk-tuks to use Makah Al-Mukarama road especially areas close to main entrance of Villa Somalia. The ministry of Interior stated that the ban is related to security matters and not suspending tuk-tuk operations. A police officer at the scene shot and killed one of the protestors. Other SNG police at the scene arrested the perpetrators.

source: Agence France Presse; Tanzania Daily News
notes: CUF activists gather in Stone Town after CUF frontrunner Seif Sharif Hamad declared himself the winner of presidential elections. Police used water cannons and tear gas to disperse crowds. Reports of 5 injured from bullets.

Two opposition lawmakers from the CNRP were beaten outside parliament during a demonstration in support of the ruling party. The two victims were attacked in their vehicles as they tried to leave the national assembly, where hundreds of protesters were gathered to demand the resignation of the legislature's deptuy president.
Unknown group fired at protesters near Kamenge Youth Center. No injuries reported at protests.

assoc_actor_1: MDC-T: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)
notes: After about 200 MDC-T supporters gathered near a court house, Police dispersed the crowds , assaulting MDC-T members and Journalists.
Moroccan forces "brutally repressed" a demonstration by Saharawi activists, leaving several injured.

assoc_actor_1: Students (Sudan); Police Forces of Sudan (1989-) National Intelligence and Security Services
notes: NCP students backed by police and NISS attacked Darfuri students during a protest at Koran University in Omdurman, using machetes and guns. 6 Darfuri students injured. Some students missing.

Workers from the Religious Endowments Ministry (MRE) protested outside Abdin Palace on 11th October, demanding permanent contracts and delayed dues dating back to 2011, but security dispersed the group during the night. Several workers suffered from bruising after being beaten by riot police.
Police forces violently dispersed Guinean civilians protesting in from of the Guinean embassy in Freetown over electoral card distributions. One person was severely injured and 20 arrested.
Continued protests at Gitega Prison. Police entered prison with machine guns, rocket launchers and tear gas, and allegedly beat alleged coup plotters that were protesting.

actor1: Police Forces of Burundi (2005-) Prison Guards
source: Deutsche Welle; Local Source Project Project
notes: Coup leader General Cyrille Ndayirukiye was severely beaten, shot in the head, and restrained by armed police in the Gitega prison, while prisoners were protesting for new construction of isolation cells.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

MINSUCA forces allegedly fired upon the several hundred marchers who were heading to the Office of the President to demand the resignation of the President with live bullets, killing 3 and injuring several, but UN sources dispute this. Most sources agree that three were killed.

Residents at Wolwerivier protest against the relocation of people from other overcrowded settlements to the area. The police respond by firing rubber bullets and beating the protesters resulting in serior injuries.

On September 18th, 40 protesters from different groups were injured when police used tear gas and batons on a large crowd which had formed in Charsadda to protest against power outages. The injured were taken to police stations.

actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-2019)

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit

notes: Protesters flocked to the presidential palace, where military forces were holding the president and prime minister captive. Gunfire was heard, and one protester was killed.
In Dhanusha, three protestors were killed in police firing in Janakpur during demonstrations on Friday [11 September]. The police had fired at the protestors for defying a curfew.

Police used force against high school students, and assaulted three reporters, at a rally against Higher Education El-Sayed Abdel Khalek organised by the students and their parents in front of the ministry in downtown Cairo, demanding acceptance into college.
On Wednesday [9 September], police opened fire on an anti-VAT demonstration by students of East West University in Dhaka, leaving more than 20 people injured, many by bullets.
Protests against water shortages. Police fired tear gas. 2 women injured and taken to the hospital.

On September 8th, 30 doctors were injured, around half of them hospitalized, after police baton charged their sit-in protest at Nadra Chowk, Islamabad. They were demanding the unfreezing of their health risk allowance.
Saharawi students held a "peaceful demonstration" to condemn recent elections. The protest was "violently dispersed" by Moroccan forces.
Police dispersed a demonstration against a proposed reconciliation bill firing teargas and beating people with batons. Several young people were arrested, while others wounded.

Police fire rubber bullets into a crowd of protesting students from the University of South Africa during a demonstration in Durban, causing severe injuries. The students were protesting against new fees and the closure of exam halls.

Police severely beat student protest leader Jean Pierre Randrianamboarina before taking him to jail. The government later opened an investigation, and admitted that some of the officers may have "crossed the line".
Protests against the demolishing of El Kheriat neighborhood in southeast Khartoum. Police arrested and beat 21 protesters.
One person died and several were injured when an army patrol team opened fire "for no apparent reason" on protesters in the Musaga neighborhood of Bujumbura.

assoc_actor_2: ANNFSU: All Nepal National Free Students' Union
notes: Over ten students were hurt on 26 August when policemen rained batons on students who were staging a rally in Dhangadhi against the government decision to hike the price of petroleum products. The rally was organised by the All Nepal National Free Students' Union.

Security guards at Chromax mine fire live ammo at EFF and community protesters demanding the compliance of the mine to the corporate social responsibility agreements and the provision of training and jobs to the local community. A community leader is injured during the protest.
Riot police in Guinea used tear gas to break up a rally on Saturday demanding the return of a former military ruler who wants to run for president despite facing charges related to a 2009 killing.
Two protesters succumbed to bullet injuries on Monday [10 August] when police opened fire at protesters in Surkhet district.
A man died during a protest staged in Colombo on 9 August 2015 against the arrest of a woman. Police allegedly assaulted the man which resulted in his death.

IS (Daesh) [formerly ISIS/ISIL] opened fire on a group of women demonstrators in Sirte, injuring some and arresting five. The women were demonstrating against the sentences passed by a Tripoli court on members of the former Al-Qadhafi regime.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: Resurgence of the Abolitionist Movement
notes: 100 IRA anti-slavery protesters in Nouakchott demand release of their leader and one of his aides who were arrested. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse protesters, injuring 6. 23 arrested.
Police beat up students protesting against power cuts.

2 demonstrators opposed to President Nkurunziza were wounded by police gunfire as they protested near a campaign rally by the CNDD-FDD in an area with many opponents of the current president. As tensions between the groups rose, police opened fire on the opposition demonstrators.

Multiple vendors including leaders of National Vendors Union of Zimbabwe, Sten Zvorwadza and Samuel Wadzai were beaten up and arrested by police after demonstrating against confiscation of their wares.
Moroccan security forces forcifully dispersed a sit-in organized by the Local Coordination of Unemployed Saharawi Graduates, injuring at least one protester.
Locals protested against a land grabbing group. During the protest, land grabbers opened fire on the protesters, injuring 7.

assoc_actor_2: MDC-T: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)

Farmers gathered to protest insufficient compensation for farmland siezed to build an industrial park. One 54-year-old woman died after being crushed by a bulldozer backed by police during the protest. The incident was filmed by witnesses, the footage of which shows the woman pinned underneath the bulldozer while onlookers shout in vain to get the driver to stop. The woman was severely injured.

The Sindh Abadgar Tanzeem (SAT) held a protest against water shortages and water thieves in Malkani. The protest camp was attacked by those believed to be involved in the water thieving and set the camp on fire. They also assaulted the protesters.

A Besigye supporter is shot by a member of Police Forces during a protest by the opposition in Najjanankumbi. The protester survived the shooting.

The police allegedly disrupt a peaceful protest by the CWU outside the head offices of MTN, a company currently engaged in an industrial dispute with the CWU. The police use rubber bullets and stun grenades resulting in serious injuries.
A Police officer shot a young boy in the legs, wounding him. Refusing to let police forces investigate houses, tensions arise.
A 23-year-old student was killed on Friday during a protest in Diyarb Najm in Sharqiya governorate. The student, who was a passer-by, was shot by anonymous assailants.

People protest inside the neighbourhood to avoid clashes with police forces. Local source reports that police shot protesters and entered into some houses. One person was shot.
Protesters rally in areas where Imbonerakure took previously-arrested demonstrators. During the protests in Mbizi, an individual was injured by a police bullet, and 3 people were arrested.

People demonstrated, demanding the release of 8 people arrested a few days ago. Police forces opened fire, and wounding a young girl.

One worker died from a fatal shot to the neck, while one of the injured was shot in the leg. Conflicting report: According to the military, the deceased worker was injured at the factory and was rushed to the hospital, along with three other colleagues, when militants purportedly fired at them.

Hundreds protested in Matana and police responded with live ammunition. Reports indicate police beat a demonstrator to death, injured three others, and arrested several.

Following the death of a civilian in custody, a dozen local residents gathered in front of the police station in the Beheira governorate, accusing the police of torturing him to death. They were dispersed by force, and there were at least eight injuries reported.

Clashes broke out between Cairo University students and administrative security guards (Falcon security guards) leaving many injured and one student dead. Central Security Forces occupied the campus following the clashes. Un-uniformed men with weapons, including electric batons and knives were fighting alongside the campus security, severely beating students.

Egyptian riot police attacked Muslim Brotherhood demonstrators in Alexandria's el-Safira neighborhood, firing bird shots and tear gas. A number of people were wounded and some others arrested in the incident.

Civil society activists protest outside the South African embassy in Harare against ongoing xenophobic attacks against Zimbabweans in South Africa. The police violently diserpse the protesters and beat them with batons.
Saharawi human rights activist attacked by policemen after participating in a peaceful political demonstration calling for self-determination in the Western Sahara.

Anti-election demonstration on at campus at El Fasher University. Police and NCP student members used batons, tear gas and live bullets to stop 200 student protesters from entering the city center. 2 women students wounded and 12 detained and taken to an unknown location.
Thousands of displaced from Murnei camp protested elections in Freedom Square at the center of Murnei. Police and militia in vehicles injured 5 protesters with bullet wounds.

Police detained over 250 protesting farmers after severely beating many of them outside the press club.
A woman was killed, allegedly by police, during a demonstration in Malindi to protest against the tax increase by the Kilifi county government. Police deny they used live rounds.
Moroccan security forces reportedly violently dispersed a demonstration for Sahrawi self-determination.
